Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration: The NSF (MCB) CAREER program supports early career faculty involved in fundamental molecular and cellular biosciences research, investing in their development as leading scholar-educators in their fields. Building on the success of the 2019 MCB CAREER Awardee Conference, the 2020 meeting will bring together awardees from MCB and NSF programs in other disciplines, including mathematical and physical sciences and engineering, to foster a cross-disciplinary research community.<br/><br/>The goals of the conference are to share knowledge and seed collaborations among early-career faculty spanning a broad range of research interests and expertise, and to provide feedback to the NSF on new research frontiers, especially at the interfaces of disciplines within and outside of biology.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: University of Pittsburgh
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

POR.DRECONTENT:
There were two main outcomes from this grant: 1) a virtual NSF CAREER awardee workshop that was held in November of 2021 and 2) an in-person NSF CAREER awardee workshop that was held in November of 2022. Originally, we had planned host an in person meeting for Fall of 2020, however, the COVID 19 pandemic necessitated cancelling this meeting. We then rescheduled the in person meeting for the Fall of 2021 but had to cancel the in person meeting that year as well. Rather than have a cohort of NSF CAREER awardees miss out on the opportunity to share their science and broader impacts with their colleagues, we hosted a virtual meeting using the GatherTown platform in Nov 2021. This event brought together 47 NSF CAREER awardees, their trainees and NSF program officers for discussions of research objectives, outreach and teaching practices and the possibility for interdisciplinary, collaborative research efforts. The event was highly successful as participants reported having impactful discussions with their colleagues that could spark new collaborative initiatives. 

In November of 2022, we hosted the in-person NSF CAREER awardee workshop and ~60 awardees attended. Here again, we had a dynamic exchange of ideas surrounding research collaborations and best practices in teaching and outreach. Enthusiasm and positive outcomes from the in-person event were very high with many attendees indicating that they planned to follow up on conversations and ideas generated at the meeting, many of which seemed likley to directly aid in new collaborative studies.
